person.note: Mary Virginia Montgomery was enslaved to Joseph Davis upon her birth in 1850. She and her family were emancipated during the Civil War. Virginia began her diary in January 1872 while living with her family at Davis Bend, Mississippi. When the diary concludes in December 1872, she is attending Oberlin College inOberlin, Ohio.

Benjamin Thornton Montgomery was born in Virginia in approximately 1819 and was purchased by Joseph Davis> in 1837. He married Mary Lewis Montgomery in 1840. Together with his family, he lived in Davis Bend, Mississippi in 1872.

Mary Lewis Montgomery was the mother of Mary Virginia Montgomery. She was born in Mississippi in the early 1820s and married Montgomery's father, Benjamin Thornton Montgomery in approximately 1840. The couple had four children together: William Thornton, Isaiah Thornton, Mary Virginia, and Rebecca C. The family was enslaved by Joseph Davis until 1862. Together with her husband and two daughters, Mary Lewis Montgomery lived at Brierfield plantation in Davis Bend, Mississippi, in 1872.
Rebecca C. Montgomery was four years younger than her sister, Virginia. Like her sister, she also attended Oberlin College starting in November 1872.

Isaiah, or "Zie," Montgomerywas the second child of Benjamin and Mary Montgomery and was three years older than his sister Virginia. He married Martha Robb in 1871. In 1872, he cultivated the Hurricane plantation acreage not rented out to tenants and managed the office above the Montgomery family store.
Born on March 4, 1872, Willie Montgomery was the son of Isaiah Montgomery and Martha, or Mattie, Robb Montgomery.

William T. Montgomery was the eldest son of Benjamin Montgomery and Mary Montgomery. Born in 1843 in Davis Bend, Mississippi William, like the rest of his family, was enslaved by Joseph Davis. On July 15, 1863, he enlisted in the United States Navy as an officer's steward on the USS Carondelet. He returned to immediately after the end of the Civil War. In 1884, William moved to Dakota Territory where he had a large farm. He returned to Mississippi in , settling in Mound Bayou with the rest of his siblings. He died there in 1909.
Virginia C. Green was born in Ohio around 1845. She came to Davis Bend to teach recently enslaved children at the end of the Civil War.

was born in 1833 in either Ohio or Pennsylvania. She was a teacher and activist, first in Pittsburgh and then in Chatham, where she moved in the spring of 1856. She married Isaac D. Shaddseveral months later. In 1870, the Shadds moved to Mississippi, where Amelia Shadd taught, first in Davis Bend and then, in 1872, in Vicksburg. Her date of death is unknown.

Isaac D. Shadd was likely born in 1829 in Wilmington, Delaware. He was the son of antislavery and civil rights activist Abraham Doras Shadd and the brother of activist and journalist Mary Ann Shadd Cary. He married Amelia Freemanin 1856. He and his wife moved to Davis Bend, Mississippi in 1870, where he may have worked as a bookkeeper for W. T. Montgomery. He moved to Vicksburg, Mississippi in 1827, where he was elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives.

Barriteer L. Hickman was born in Virginia but moved to St. Louis, Missouri, with his parents when he was a young child. In 1870, when he was eighteen years old, he was living with his parents in St. Louis and working as a life insurance agent. It is not clear how he met the Montgomery family or when he moved to Davis Bend to work as a bookkeeper. Mary Virginia Montgomery worked as his assistant.

Chlote Green was born in approximately 1863 to Isaac Green and Kitty or Katie Jane Lewis, the sister of Mary Lewis Montgomery. In the early 1870s, she and her brother Benjamin Greenlived with the Montgomery family at Brierfield.
Mary Street lived at Davis Bend with her mother, Lucy. Both Mary and her mother were born in Virginia. According to the 1870 census, neither could read or write. Mary worked as a farm hand.

Toney Lewis, or "Uncle Toney," was likely the brother of Mary Lewis Montgomery. According to the 1870 census, he lived in Davis Bend with a woman who was either a much younger wife or an older child (thirty years old to his forty-nine), Virginia, and eight children, six of whom had the last name "Lewis."
was the daughter of Martha Brooks, or "Aunt Martha," a cook who lived with and worked for the Montgomery family.

Joshua Montgomery was the cousin of Virginia Montgomery. It is unclear whether his mother or his father was a sibling of Benjamin Montgomery.Joshua appears to have worked with his uncle as a mechanic and in other capacities.

Henry Hardin or Harding was born around 1830. According to the 1870 census, he lived with Hannah Hardin, fifty years old, and two children: four-year-old Shephard and an infant named M.G. He could not read or write, which explains why Virginia writes a letter for him on 26 January.

Bejamin Titus Green was born in 1854 to Isaac Green and Kitty or Katie Jane Lewis, the sister of Mary Lewis Montgomery. In the early 1870s, he and his sister Chlote Greenlived with the Montgomery family at Brierfield.
George Owen was the inventor of the Owen Double Plow and Cultivator, or, as it was sometimes called, the Owen Twin Plow and Cultivator. He visited the Montgomery family a number of times in 1872.

Rachel Lewis was the mother of Mary Lewis Montgomery and the grandmother of Mary Virginia Montgomery. Rachel Lewis and her husband William Lewis, Sr. were likely born in Virginia, but were purchased by Joseph E. Davis and moved to Davis Bend earlier than Benjamin Montgomery.

was born in Mississippi in approximately 1847. In the 1870 census, she is living at Davis Bend with her husband Calvin and her three-year-old daughter, Nannie. By 1880, they were living in Goosey Precinct, Yazoo County.

Sarah McGinnis and her husband William lived in Bolivar County, Mississippi, with their three children Sarah, Edward, and Lucy. Prior to her marriage to Isaiah Montgomery, Martha Robb Montgomery lived with the McGinnis family. It is not clear how she knew them.

Abraham W. Shadd was the younger brother of Isaac D. Shadd. After recieving his law degree from Howard University in 1871, he moved to Mississippi, where he served as an attorney and a public official.
Laz Scharff was the younger brother of Moses Scharff and, in 1870, lived with him and his family in Vicksburg. He likely worked for his elder brother at Scharff Bros. selling dry goods and clothing.

note.persName: Moses Scharff lived in Vicksburg, Mississippi, with his wife and small children, as well as several brothers. Along with at least one brother, he had a dry goods and clothing business called Scharff Bros. By 1830, he and his family had moved to St. Louis, Missouri. The Scharffs were likely part of an active and organized Jewish community in Vicksburg, established around 1830.

Joshua W. Bourne, or Captain Bourne, as Virginia calls him in her diary, was a former Union solder who settled in Vicksburg after the Civil War. He became a politician, serving as county assessor and deputy collector of internal revenue before he was murdered during a duel in 1884.

person.note: "Joe" is likely Josephine Robinson, who lives with Edward and Nancy Robinson in Davis Bend in 1870. Her relationship to them is unclear. On 4 May, 1872, Josephine married Charles Miller. By 1880, the couple lived in Vicksburg, Mississippi.
Jack (J. H.) Lewis was likely the brother of Mary Lewis Montgomery.

Benjamin Ousley was enslaved by Joseph E. Davis and lived at Davis Bend until 1870, when, dissatisfied with Benjamin Montgomery's rental terms, he led a group of about twenty-five residents from Davis Bend to a plantation near Glencoe in Bolivar County. Relations between Ousley and Montgomery seem to have remained friendly, as he dined with the family on 13 March and their children remained friendly.

Joseph E. Ousley was the son of Benjamin Ousley and was enslaved by Joseph E. Davis until the Civil War. He followed his father to Bolivar County in 1870, but remained friendly with the Montgomery family, visiting them in May 1872.
Moses Lewis was likely the brother of Mary Lewis Montgomery.

note.persName: Evan Walker was the son of Harry and Rose Walker of Davis Bend. He was twenty years old in 1872.

person.note: Samuel Cox was born in Virginia and enslaved on Davis Bend. In 1870, he followed Benjamin Ousley to Bolivar County. On the 1870 census, he is listed as living with Jordan Green, another former resident of Davis Bend, in Bolivar County.

note.persName: Charles Miller married a seamstress named Josephine in 1872. He is mentioned only a handful of times in MVM's diary.

person.note: Jeff Watson was born in Virginia in 1895. It is not clear whether he was actually related to the Montgomerys or was called "Uncle" out of respect for his advanced age. He was married to Harriet Watson.

note.persName: Harriet Watson was born in Mississippi.

person.note: Alice Brookswas the daughter of Martha Brooks, who lived with the Montgomery family and worked as their cook in the 1870s.
Ulysses S. Grant served as the eighteenth President of the United States from 1869 to 1877.

note.persName: Catherine Wiggins lived with the family of William Lewis, MVM's maternal uncle, close to Brierfield. It is not clear what her relationship to the family was. Her class status is indicated by the fact that MVM calls her "Miss Wiggins."

person.note: Virginia Montgomery did not know personally, but she seems to have subscribed to one of her magazines--either Mme. Demorest's Mirror of Fashions or Demorest's Illustrated Monthly Magazine--and likely acquired dressmaking patterns from her company, as she describes writing "to Mme Demorest" on 21 February.
Lucy Jane Lewis was the wife of Moses Lewis, the brother of MVM's mother, Mary Lewis Montgomery.

Helen Elizabeth Martin was Assistant Principal of the Women's Department at Oberlin College from 1866 to 1874 and 1875 to 1876.
Reverend Judson Smith taught Latin and History from 1866 to 1884.
Adelia A. Field Johnston was principal of the Ladies' Department at Oberlin College from 1870 to 1900.
Anna Wyatt was not listed in the Oberlin catalogue for 1872-1873, but she seems to have provided drawing lessons to students at Oberlin.
Miss Loomis was a student at Oberlin College in late 1872. There were at least four young women named Loomis attending Oberlin that fall, so it is impossible to say which one MVM refers to.
Harriet Hinman was a student in the English School at Oberlin College in the 1872-1873 academic year.
Lillie Scidmore, born as Eliza Ruhamah Scidmore, was a student at Oberlin College in 1872-1873.

person.occupation: Teacher of Greek at Oberlin College

person.note: W. B. Shelby was the Democratic candidate for the Mississippi House of Representatives, from District 5, running against the Republican candidate, George C. McKee.
